item.description:
Haji defends Khawar Qureshi choice, says 'war' expected  Daily Nation

Queen's Counsel Khawar Qureshi's appointment to Deputy Chief Justice Philomena Mwilu's case is not a new phenomenon, Director of Public Prosecutions ...

item.title: Prosecution fails to confirm withdrawal of criminal charges against businessman Wanjigi and co-accused - Standard Digital
item.description:
Prosecution fails to confirm withdrawal of criminal charges against businessman Wanjigi and co-accused  Standard Digital

The Director of Public Prosecutions has failed to confirm the withdrawal of a case against businessman Jimi Wanjigi.

item.description:
DPP loses bid to lock out NLC chairman from office  The Standard

Director of Public Prosecution Noordin Haji has failed in his quest to eject National Lands Commission boss Mohammed Swazuri from office. ALSO READ: ...

item.title: Blow for DPP as Swazuri office access order is upheld - Business Daily
item.description:
Blow for DPP as Swazuri office access order is upheld  Business Daily

The Director of Public Prosecutions Tuesday suffered a blow after the High Court declined to review an order allowing National Land Commission chairman.

item.title: DPP loses bid to stop Swazuri from accessing his office - Citizen TV
item.description:
DPP loses bid to stop Swazuri from accessing his office  Citizen TV

The Director of Public Prosecution has lost a bid to have National Lands Commission Chairman Mohammed Swazuri barred from accessing his office.

item.title: DPP Haji's tough search for special prosecutors - VIDEO - Daily Nation
item.description:
DPP Haji's tough search for special prosecutors - VIDEO  Daily Nation

Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) Noordin Haji has invited more lawyers to join his panel of private counsel offering his office legal services, as he seeks to ...

item.title: DPP appeals against order allowing Swazuri access to office - Capital FM Kenya
item.description:
DPP appeals against order allowing Swazuri access to office  Capital FM Kenya

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec 5 – Director of Public Prosecutions Noordin Haji will move to the Court of Appeal to challenge a decision by the High Court declining ...

item.title: DPP requests for more time on case against PCEA moderator - Kenya Broadcasting Corporation
item.description:
DPP requests for more time on case against PCEA moderator  Kenya Broadcasting Corporation

The office of the DPP has for the third time in a row pleaded for more time to give directions in a case against former PCEA moderator David Gathanju.

item.title: DPP Haji appoints London based lawyer Qureshi, to handle high profile cases : KTN News - The Standard
item.description:
DPP Haji appoints London based lawyer Qureshi, to handle high profile cases : KTN News  The Standard

The office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has appointed a London legal consultant Khawar Qureshi as its lead prosecutor.

item.title: DPP Haji wants all charged public servants suspended from office - Standard Digital
item.description:
DPP Haji wants all charged public servants suspended from office  Standard Digital

Several high profile individuals including governors and senior officers in government have cases pending before courts.

item.title: Man who served 19 years in jail for top cop's murder found not guilty in retrial - ABC News
item.description:
Man who served 19 years in jail for top cop's murder found not guilty in retrial  ABC News

By Elizabeth Byrne and staff David Eastman, who spent nearly 20 years in jail over the killing of one of the country's top cops, has been found not guilty of the murder after a retrial. A jury found Mr Eastman, now 73, not guilty of murdering senior Australian Federal Police officer Colin Winchester nearly three decades ago. The not guilty verdict in the packed ACT Supreme Court marked the end of a six-month trial and just over a week of deliberating. The tension among police, court staff, journalists and spectators who had spent many days listening to the evidence was palpable. Mr Eastman ...

item.title: Criminal cases in doubt after DNA scientist sacked - ABC News
item.description:
Criminal cases in doubt after DNA scientist sacked  ABC News

The sacking of WA's leading DNA scientist over allegations he breached testing protocols is an "unprecedented disaster" in the state's criminal history, Attorney-General John Quigley says. Mr Quigley said Laurence Webb, the senior forensic biologist with the state-run pathology centre Path West, had been dismissed for failing to follow established protocols. He said Mr Webb's dismissal cast doubt on the convictions of at least 27 people, including those involved in a number of high-profile murder cases. Mr Quigley said Mr Webb was sacked in August 2016 following an investigations by PathWes...

item.title: Prosecutors are considering manslaughter charges after Grenfell Tower disaster, Keir Starmer reveals - The Telegraph
item.description:
Prosecutors are considering manslaughter charges after Grenfell Tower disaster, Keir Starmer reveals  The Telegraph

A Criminal investigation into the Grenfell Tower tragedy is looking into manslaughter charges, Sir Keir Starmer has said. The shadow Brexit Secretary, who is also the former Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), revealed prosecutors were currently part of the investigation. He said they would be looking at whether anyone could be charged with manslaughter following a litany of failings that led to the disaster - in which at least at least 58 people are now feared to have been killed. Urban Search and Rescue officers from London Fire Brigade inside the Grenfell Tower in west LondonCredit: D...

item.title: A paedophile arranged the kidnapping of trial witnesses — but did he break the law? - ABC News
item.description:
A paedophile arranged the kidnapping of trial witnesses — but did he break the law?  ABC News

The ACT's Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) has asked the High Court to find a convicted paedophile broke the law when he urged another man to organise a kidnapping. Canberra man Aaron James Holliday, 31, is serving an eight-year sentence for sex offences against three boys. While he was waiting for his trial Holliday asked another prisoner to find someone on the outside to kidnap two key witnesses and force them to retract their evidence. He typed an eight-page document which included instructions about recording the retractions and where to find the intended victims. But the kidnappin...

item.title: Grenfell fire: criminal charges with long prison terms not ruled out - The Guardian
item.description:
Grenfell fire: criminal charges with long prison terms not ruled out  The Guardian

The director of public prosecutions, Alison Saunders, has not ruled out possible criminal charges carrying lengthy prison sentences against individuals over the Grenfell Tower fire. In her first public comments since the disaster, she said investigations were at a very early stage. All options remained open, but it could take months before charging decisions can be made, she said. About 80 people are believed to have died in the fire in west London. Gross negligence manslaughter is among offences prosecutors could consider if police find sufficient evidence. The offence carries a maximum se...

item.title: South African prosecuting authority reviewing Roebuck inquest findings - ESPNCricinfo
item.description:
South African prosecuting authority reviewing Roebuck inquest findings  ESPNCricinfo

South Africa's Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), Western Province, has begun reviewing the findings of the original closed inquest into the death of Peter Roebuck, raising the prospects of the incident being re-examined. The original inquest had taken place without any representatives of the former Somerset captain, writer and broadcaster or his family. The DPP is part of South Africa's National Prosecution Authority, a body with the power to institute criminal proceedings on behalf of the State. The original inquest "docket" had been requested for review by the DPP advocate Julius Mor...

item.title: Prosecutor tipped to tell Lucille Butterworth's family murder charge not possible - ABC News
item.description:
Prosecutor tipped to tell Lucille Butterworth's family murder charge not possible  ABC News

The Lucille Butterworth murder case is set to come to a head tomorrow with Tasmania's top prosecutor expected to tell her family he will not be prosecuting the man named as her killer in the coronial inquest. The part-time model disappeared from a bus stop in the Hobart suburb of Claremont in August 1969. An inquest into her disappearance began in 2015. The man named as the main person of interest to the inquest, Geoffrey Charles Hunt, gave evidence and denied he had anything to do with her disappearance. Mr Hunt was jailed in 1976 for the rape and murder of Hobart car saleswoman Susan Knig...

item.title: Couple fails in Court of Appeal challenge over change to assisted dying policy - The Telegraph
item.description:
Couple fails in Court of Appeal challenge over change to assisted dying policy  The Telegraph

Disability rights campaigners have failed in a bid to challenge the Director of Public Prosecution’s policy on assisted dying which they fear leaves vulnerable people “at risk from dodgy doctors”. The Court of Appeal today told Nikki and Merv Kenward it was “futile” to allow them permission to appeal against an earlier High Court ruling that Alison Saunders’s updated advice does not breach the Suicide Act. Although it does raise difficult and delicate issues, it does seem entirely inappropriate that the case should go any furtherLord Justice Longmore The 1961 legislation makes assisting or ...

item.title: APOLOGY - The Telegraph
item.description:
APOLOGY  The Telegraph

In our reporting of the public debate surrounding the decision to prosecute two former British Soldiers for the alleged murder of Joe McCann, we published inaccurate statements concerning Barra McGrory QC, the Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern Ireland, including allegations that the decision by him was in revenge for the murder of IRA terrorists and/or was politically motivated. We accept that this was incorrect and that the decision was made in accordance with proper practice and pursuant to established criteria. We apologise for the distress caused to Mr McGrory QC and we have...

item.title: Geoffrey Hunt won't be charged over Lucille Butterworth's murder - ABC News
item.description:
Geoffrey Hunt won't be charged over Lucille Butterworth's murder  ABC News

The Tasmanian Director of Public Prosecutions will not be charging the man named by the coroner as Lucille Butterworth's killer. Lucille Butterworth was 20 when she vanished from a Hobart bus stop in 1969. Last year, coroner Simon Cooper found she had been strangled by Geoffrey Charles Hunt, a neighbour of her boyfriend. Hunt has denied any involvement. In a statement, Daryl Coates SC said he was asked by police to advise "on whether any person could be charged with causing Miss Butterworth's death". He pointed out how a criminal prosecution differed to a coronial inquest in terms of provin...

item.title: Kenya: 2 Iranian Men in Israeli Embassy Case are Deported - VOA News
item.description:
Kenya: 2 Iranian Men in Israeli Embassy Case are Deported  VOA News

Two Iranian men who were found with video footage of the Israeli Embassy in Kenya have been deported after a deal was reached to drop charges against them, Kenyan officials said Monday. The two men had faced charges of collecting information to facilitate a terrorist attack. They were deported Saturday after a court order, the head of Kenya's anti-terrorism unit, Munga Nyale, said. Their lawyer, Ahmednasir Abdulahi, said they were deported because there was no evidence in the charges they faced. The prosecution has said an agreement to deport them was reached after a meeting between the Dir...

item.title: Years to go to trial but 32 minutes to convict — Attorney-General calls for explanation - ABC News
item.description:
Years to go to trial but 32 minutes to convict — Attorney-General calls for explanation  ABC News

The New South Wales Attorney-General has issued a please explain to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) over its handling of the Lynette Daley manslaughter saga. Two men were yesterday found guilty over the 33-year-old's death, with a Supreme Court jury taking just 32 minutes to reach its verdicts. Despite a thorough police investigation in 2011 and coronial findings in 2014 which strongly recommended charges be laid, the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions did not prosecute the men. The jury's swift conviction in the matter has led to questions about why the DPP waited so l...

item.title: Man dies after being shot in head while out with friends in SA forest - ABC News
item.description:
Man dies after being shot in head while out with friends in SA forest  ABC News

A man who was shot while cutting wood and "messing around" with friends at Parawa, south of Adelaide, has died in hospital, police have said. A 28-year-old male has been charged with committing an act to endanger life but it is possible a murder charge may be laid after the victim was shot in the head yesterday afternoon, police said. Hayden Dove Fenton appeared in Christies Beach Magistrates Court this afternoon and remains in custody. Detective Inspector Greg Hutchins said the 21-year-old victim, from Hayborough, was one of five friends, four men and a woman, who had taken a gun out to th...

item.title: DPP accuses judge of 'victim-blaming' in sex assault cases - The Guardian
item.description:
DPP accuses judge of 'victim-blaming' in sex assault cases  The Guardian

The head of the Crown Prosecution Service has launched a public attack on a sitting judge, accusing him of “victim-blaming” and peddling “discredited rape myths”. Alison Saunders, the director of public prosecutions, said it was “disappointing” that Judge Philip Shorrock had expressed views that “lean in favour of [...] ‘victim blaming’ culture”, after he wrote to the Telegraph that most trials led to the alleged rapist being “unsurprisingly” acquitted because both parties had been drinking or taking drugs, and there was no independent proof of rape. The DPP said: “It is always disappointin...

item.title: CPS to crack down on social media hate crime, says Alison Saunders - The Guardian
item.description:
CPS to crack down on social media hate crime, says Alison Saunders  The Guardian

Prosecutors will be ordered to treat online hate crime as seriously as offences carried out face to face in plans announced by the director of public prosecutions. Alison Saunders said the Crown Prosecution Service will seek stiffer penalties for abuse on Twitter, Facebook and other social media platforms. Related: Hate is hate. Online abusers must be dealt with harshly | Alison Saunders Saunders says the crackdown is needed because online abuse can lead to the sort of extremist hate seen in Charlottesville in the United States last weekend, which left one person dead. Writing in the Guardi...

item.title: Lynette Daley trial: Jury takes less than an hour to reach guilty verdicts - ABC News
item.description:
Lynette Daley trial: Jury takes less than an hour to reach guilty verdicts  ABC News

Two men have been found guilty over the death of Lynette Daley, who died after a violent sexual act on a remote beach in northern New South Wales in 2011. Key points: - Adrian Attwater and Paul Maris had long been suspects in Lynette Daly's 2011 death - A Four Corners story in May 2016 prompted an independent review of the DPP decision not to prosecute the men - Attwater and Maris were charged the following month, and a jury today took less than an hour to convict them After listening to weeks of evidence and cross examination, a jury at the Supreme Court in Coffs Harbour deliberated for le...

item.title: Chief prosecutor trying former soldiers over alleged murder of IRA man should step down, says MP - The Telegraph
item.description:
Chief prosecutor trying former soldiers over alleged murder of IRA man should step down, says MP  The Telegraph

The prosecutor trying two former soldiers for the murder of an IRA commander in Northern Ireland 44 years ago should be forced to step down because of his links to Republicans, a senior Tory MP has said. Sir Gerald Howarth has written a letter to Theresa May asking her call on Barra McGrory, the Director of Public Prosecutions in Northern Ireland, to step aside from the case. Mr McGrory, before taking up his official posting, acted as solicitor to Martin McGuinness, the Sinn Fein politician and former IRA commander, at the Bloody Sunday inquiry and represented on-the-run terror suspects in ...

item.title: Britain to Treat Internet Hate Crime as Seriously as Offline Offenses - VOA News
item.description:
Britain to Treat Internet Hate Crime as Seriously as Offline Offenses  VOA News

Online abuse will be treated as seriously as offline offences, Britain's prosecution service said on Monday in new guidance on handling hate crimes. The rules - which included guidelines on helping disabled and bisexual victims - were meant to encourage more people to come forward and press courts to impose longer sentences, the Crown Prosecution Service said. "This is a crime that's under-reported. Sometimes people feel that they just have to put up with it ... That's absolutely not the case," Alison Saunders, the director of public prosecutions, told the BBC. The new advice was in respons...

item.title: Hospital ERs to get child safety officers in wake of toddler's death - ABC News
item.description:
Hospital ERs to get child safety officers in wake of toddler's death  ABC News

Child safety officers will be put in emergency rooms at hospitals across Queensland as part of the State Government's response to the death of Caboolture toddler Mason Jet Lee. The Queensland Government has decided to withhold the Queensland Family and Child Commission's final report on a review of the 21-month-old's death, on the advice of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). The report found Queensland's system of reviewing the deaths of children was not sufficiently independent, was not delivering the whole-of-system changes required to protect vulnerable children, and that "Queens...

item.title: Ten years on: How the Woolmer investigation was botched - ESPNCricinfo
item.description:
Ten years on: How the Woolmer investigation was botched  ESPNCricinfo

Ten years after the death of Bob Woolmer at the 2007 World Cup, the then-Jamaican Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) has been strongly criticised for his role in and behaviour during the subsequent inquest. In November 2007, a jury at the coroner's inquest returned an open verdict on Woolmer's death despite evidence pointing towards natural causes. Experts and officials involved with the case feel the influence of the DPP, Kent Pantry, was crucial in attempting to discredit evidence that pointed away from the murder theory proffered by the state pathologist Dr Ere Seshaiah. Three indepen...

item.title: Libya rendition case against ex-MI6 officer may be held partly in secret - The Guardian
item.description:
Libya rendition case against ex-MI6 officer may be held partly in secret  The Guardian

A legal attempt to prosecute the former senior MI6 officer Sir Mark Allen for his alleged role in the rendition and torture of Libyan dissidents may be heard partially in secret. The decision by the director of public prosecutions (DPP), Alison Saunders, not to charge Allen is being challenged at the high court by lawyers for Abdel Hakim Belhaj and his wife, Fatima Boudchar, who was pregnant when they were both abducted in 2004. The unusual procedure is being heard by the lord chief justice, Lord Thomas of Cwmgiedd, and Mr Justice Popplewell. The court has not yet determined whether it is i...

item.title: Prosecutors could examine suspected rapists' past treatment of women to increase conviction rate - The Independent
item.description:
Prosecutors could examine suspected rapists' past treatment of women to increase conviction rate  The Independent

Prosecutors could be instructed to examine alleged rapists’ past sexual behaviour and treatment of women as part of efforts to increase conviction rates. Alison Saunders, the Director of Public Prosecutions, said she wants all evidence available on a defendant to be presented in court including CCTV, social media and witness testimony covering the lead-up to attacks. “We are looking at how to prosecute certain types of cases, the more difficult ones. They tend to involve drugs or drink and people who know each other,” she told the Evening Standard. Theresa May says rape clause forcing victi...

item.title: Rape juries to hear more about men's sexual history to increase chance of conviction - The Telegraph
item.description:
Rape juries to hear more about men's sexual history to increase chance of conviction  The Telegraph

Jurors in rape trials will be told more about the previous sexual behaviour of male defendants in a bid to increase the chances of conviction. Alison Saunders, the Director of Public Prosecutions, has told prosecutors to focus on the behaviour of men leading up to alleged rapes, rather than just the incident itself. The move is intended to provide juries with a fuller picture of male suspect's character, after a series of high profile rape trials ended in acquittals. In a number of recent cases, the sexual history and behaviour of the female accuser has been presented as crucial evidence. A...

item.title: Grenfell: CPS says criminal charges with life terms could be brought against anyone found culpable - The Independent
item.description:
Grenfell: CPS says criminal charges with life terms could be brought against anyone found culpable  The Independent

The country’s most senior prosecutor has said that individuals found responsible for the Grenfell Tower fire could face lengthy prison sentences. Alison Saunders, the Director of Public Prosecutions, said that manslaughter by gross negligence were among the offences the Crown will consider if police uncover sufficient evidence, as she vowed to do everything in her power to see justice done for the victims. The offence of manslaughter by gross negligence comes with a starting point of 12 years and can carry a life sentence if offenders are found to have a “very high” level of culpability. Re...

item.title: Director of public prosecutions defends 23% fall in rape charges - The Guardian
item.description:
Director of public prosecutions defends 23% fall in rape charges  The Guardian

The new director of public prosecutions has defended the steep decline in the number of people charged with rape, but denied prosecutors were given targets to screen out weak cases. In his third week in the job, Max Hill said he understood concerns about the fall in the number of rape charges, which dropped by 23% last year to its lowest rate in a decade. But in his first interview in the role, Hill predicted the decline would not continue and suggested last year’s fall was the result of prosecutors trying to improve the “quality” of cases brought to trial. In September, the Guardian reveal...

item.title: CPS and police 'routinely failing' to disclose evidence - The Guardian
item.description:
CPS and police 'routinely failing' to disclose evidence  The Guardian

Prosecutors and police are routinely failing in their duties to disclose crucial evidence, leading to cases being pursued that should have been dropped, a review by the attorney general has found. The report, presented by Geoffrey Cox, calls for a culture of zero tolerance in the Crown Prosecution Service and police forces of any failures to hand over relevant material obtained during investigations. Related: Director of public prosecutions defends 23% fall in rape charges The duty to record, retain and review material collected during the course of inquiries was not routinely being complie...

item.title: Police spy should face charges for sexual relationship with activist, court told - The Guardian
item.description:
Police spy should face charges for sexual relationship with activist, court told  The Guardian

A woman who was deceived into an intimate relationship by an undercover police officer has gone to court to try to compel the state to prosecute him. The environmental activist is one of a number of women deceived into intimate relationships by undercover officers. The Crown Prosecution Service has so far decided not to prosecute any of them. The activist, known as Monica as she has been granted anonymity, is the first woman to take legal action in an attempt to overturn the CPS’s stance. She had what she called an “intense” six-month relationship with Jim Boyling, the undercover officer wh...

item.title: CPS prepares for a no-deal Brexit and loss of European arrest warrant - Financial Times
item.description:
CPS prepares for a no-deal Brexit and loss of European arrest warrant  Financial Times

The Crown Prosecution Service is preparing for a “no-deal” Brexit scenario that could see it no longer able to use the European arrest warrant to pursue suspected criminals abroad, the new director of public prosecutions said on Tuesday. In his first speech since taking over as DPP from Alison Saunders this month, Max Hill, QC, said the CPS was preparing for the possibility of a no deal Brexit as well as an agreed departure because of the impact that leaving the EU might have on a number of its criminal cases that have an international dimension. “If there is a ‘no deal’ the most direct imp...

item.title: ‘Barbaric and inhumane’: why do so few rapists go to jail? - ABC News
item.description:
‘Barbaric and inhumane’: why do so few rapists go to jail?  ABC News

By Stephanie Boltje and Annika Blau It's a shocking statistic that rarely budges: only one in 10 reported cases of sexual assault results in a conviction. So, what's to blame? Legal experts say lack of evidence and eyewitnesses means it's simply harder to prove than other crimes. But survivors say the system is stacked against them, with their cases hampered by constant court delays and prejudiced attitudes around what a "perfect" victim looks like. What's more, they say they're constantly re-traumatised by a "barbaric" system of cross-examination. In a two-part series of The Drum with Juli...

item.title: Crown Prosecution Service head: justice system can’t cope - The Guardian
item.description:
Crown Prosecution Service head: justice system can’t cope  The Guardian

Britain’s criminal justice system is “creaking” and unable to cope with the huge amounts of data being generated by technology, the head of the Crown Prosecution Service has warned in her final interview before stepping down. Speaking exclusively to the Observer, Alison Saunders said the CPS and police were failing to investigate thousands of cases efficiently – from rape to fraud to modern slavery – and were critically short of the skills and resources required to combat crime. Saunders, who steps down as the most senior prosecutor on Wednesday, said: “There is a huge issue to train all of...

item.title: Family urges DPP to pursue 'body in the bath' retrial - ABC News
item.description:
Family urges DPP to pursue 'body in the bath' retrial  ABC News

By Daniel Keane The family of Anna-Jane Cheney, who was found dead in the bath of her Adelaide home in 1994, has asked the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) to pursue a retrial of her fiance Henry Keogh. Mr Keogh — who has maintained his innocence throughout — told the ABC he felt he had nothing "constructive" to add to the discussion at this time. His conviction for Ms Cheney's murder was overturned in 2014 by the Court of Criminal Appeal, after it found there had been a miscarriage of justice due to flawed forensic evidence provided by Dr Colin Manock. The court directed a retrial but...

item.title: Rape prosecutions fall despite police reports rising - The Telegraph
item.description:
Rape prosecutions fall despite police reports rising  The Telegraph

The number of rape suspects charged by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) has fallen by almost a quarter over the last year, despite an increase in the number of allegations being reported to the police. In 2017-18 the CPS charged 2,822 defendants with rape, almost 850 less than the previous year and the lowest in a decade. But the fall - which continues a four year downward trend - comes at a time when complaints to the police are continuing to rise, almost doubling over the last five years. Last year there were more than 41,000 allegations of rape made to the police in England and Wales,...

item.title: Prosecutors urged to ditch 'weak' rape cases to improve figures - The Guardian
item.description:
Prosecutors urged to ditch 'weak' rape cases to improve figures  The Guardian

Prosecutors in England and Wales have been urged to take a more risk-averse approach in rape cases to help stem widespread criticism of the service’s low conviction rates, the Guardian can reveal. The controversial advice to take a proportion of “weak cases out of the system” has been given to specialist rape prosecutors in training seminars, which has led some staff to fear the service has undertaken an undeclared change in policy. The advice has also caused alarm among experts and campaigners, who say it could severely limit victims’ access to justice. They warn it could lead to cases inv...

item.title: Rape prosecutions plummet despite rise in police reports - The Guardian
item.description:
Rape prosecutions plummet despite rise in police reports  The Guardian

The number of rape cases being charged by the Crown Prosecution Service has plummeted to the lowest in a decade, despite an increase in the number of incidents reported to police, figures have revealed. The CPS charged 849fewer defendants in 2017-18 than the previous year – a 23.1% fall –according to the service’s annual Violence Against Women and Girls (VAWG) report. The report’s publication comes after the Guardian revealed that prosecutors in England and Wales have been quietly urged to take a more risk-averse approach in rape cases to help stem widespread criticism of the service’s low ...

item.title: Family demands retrial over 'body in the bath' case - ABC News
item.description:
Family demands retrial over 'body in the bath' case  ABC News

By Daniel Keane The family of Anna-Jane Cheney, who was found dead in the bath of her Adelaide home in 1994, has called for an immediate retrial of her former fiance Henry Keogh, who had his conviction for her murder overturned in 2014. His conviction was quashed by the Court of Criminal Appeal in 2014, after it found there had been a miscarriage of justice due to flawed forensic evidence provided by Dr Colin Manock. The lawyer for Ms Cheney's family, Greg Griffin, today made a statement on their behalf questioning why the Government had decided to compensate Mr Keogh without consulting the...

item.title: Kenyan governor charged in murder of pregnant student - CNN
item.description:
Kenyan governor charged in murder of pregnant student  CNN

A Kenyan governor has been charged with aiding and abetting the murder of a pregnant student with whom, prosecutors say, he was in an "intimate relationship." Gov. Okoth Obado of Migori County in western Kenya is accused of killing Sharon Otieno, 26, who was abducted September 3 alongside local journalist Barack Oduor. Oduor escaped and reported the incident to police, prosecutors say. Two days later, Otieno, who was seven months pregnant, was found by the roadside, covered in stab wounds. Her unborn baby also had stab wounds, according to local media reports. A media statement from Kenya's...

item.title: Juvenile or adult? Leap-year suspect born on February 29 causes headache for court - ABC News
item.description:
Juvenile or adult? Leap-year suspect born on February 29 causes headache for court  ABC News

By Jordan Hayne The leap day in the year 2000 has caused a headache for Canberra courts, after a girl born on February 29 of that year was charged with a crime committed exactly 18 calendar years later. The girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was initially treated as an adult when she was charged with an offence allegedly committed on February 28, 2018. As there was no February 29 in 2018, the ACT Children's Court initially found the girl had turned 18 on the day of the crime, and should be dealt with in the adult court system. But the girl's lawyers applied for a review, arguing s...

item.title: South Africa's top court orders Zuma-appointed chief prosecutor to leave post - Reuters
item.description:
South Africa's top court orders Zuma-appointed chief prosecutor to leave post  Reuters

South Africa's Constitutional Court on Monday ruled the appointment of the chief prosecutor, who was given his job after former president Jacob Zuma removed his predecessor, was invalid and ordered that he be replaced within 90 days. Shaun Abrahams was appealing against an earlier High Court judgment that ruled that the removal of predecessor Mxolisi Nxasana was unlawful and that his own appointment be revoked. Zuma faced a string of corruption allegations during his time in office, and Abrahams was accused by the opposition and rights groups of shielding the president from prosecution. Zum...

item.title: UK modern slavery offense charges jump 27% in past year - CNN
item.description:
UK modern slavery offense charges jump 27% in past year  CNN

New figures from the British Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) released Thursday showed charges for modern day slavery offenses in the UK have risen significantly in the past year. Between 2017 and 2018, 239 suspects were charged -- a 27% rise on the previous year -- while 185 modern slavery and human trafficking convictions were seen in the same period. Referrals to the CPS from police and other agencies also increased to 355, "the highest ever recorded," although the percentage charged (67.3%) was the lowest since 2013-2014. "Modern slavery has a devastating, lasting impact on its victims,"...

item.title: 'Significant injustice': Man serves twice his sentence over prosecution delays - ABC News
item.description:
'Significant injustice': Man serves twice his sentence over prosecution delays  ABC News

By Amy McCosker A West Australian man who served an extra 772 days in a central Queensland jail beyond his sentence has been "dealt a significant injustice", a prominent criminal lawyer says. Troy Allen Donovan was remanded in custody for the manslaughter of his partner Bernadine Frances Clement in 2016. Two years, two months and 21 days later, Mr Donovan finally had his day in court and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) reduced his charges after receiving medical records a week earlier. The records showed Ms Clement had prior medical conditions that were the cause of ...

item.title: Federal police set to refer tip-offs about AWU raids to the Director of Public Prosecutions - ABC News
item.description:
Federal police set to refer tip-offs about AWU raids to the Director of Public Prosecutions  ABC News

By political correspondent Louise Yaxley The Australian Federal Police (AFP) is liaising with the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions about whether charges should be laid over leaks from Federal Jobs Minister Michaelia Cash's office about raids on the Australian Workers Union. Some journalists were tipped off and waiting when Federal police officers raided union offices in Melbourne and Sydney last October to seize documents relating to donations made to Get Up and Labor candidates when Bill Shorten was head of the AWU. There has been a long-running police investigation into the le...

item.title: 'Drop the case' against men who exposed Australia's spying, pleads Nobel laureate - ABC News
item.description:
'Drop the case' against men who exposed Australia's spying, pleads Nobel laureate  ABC News

Nobel Peace Prize winner and former president of East Timor Jose Ramos-Horta says charges should be dropped against two men who exposed Australia's spying operation on the East Timor cabinet room during a lucrative oil and gas deal in 2004. Key points: - An Australian intelligence agent and his lawyer are facing charges for exposing Australia's spying operation in Timor-Leste, also known as East Timor - Attorney-General Christian Porter approved the prosecution case after advice from the Commonwealth DPP - Mr Ramos-Horta says he will also suggest the two men be given an Order of Timor-Leste...

item.title: MPs criticise DPP Alison Saunders over collapse of rape trials - The Guardian
item.description:
MPs criticise DPP Alison Saunders over collapse of rape trials  The Guardian

The director of public prosecutions, Alison Saunders, has been criticised by MPs for failing to get to grips with disclosure problems that led to the collapse of multiple rape trials. In a stinging report, the Commons justice select committee accuses her of not recognising the extent of difficulties caused by delays in releasing, or by withholding, evidence in prosecutions. A series of rape trials collapsed at the end of last year and the beginning of this year when text and social media exchanges belatedly emerged that undermined complainants’ accounts. Trials were halted and charges dropp...

item.title: Max Hill to become chief prosecutor for England and Wales - Financial Times
item.description:
Max Hill to become chief prosecutor for England and Wales  Financial Times

The man in charge of scrutinising the UK government’s terrorism legislation will become the chief prosecutor for England and Wales under plans announced on Tuesday. Max Hill, a barrister, will take over on November 1 as director of public prosecutions from Alison Saunders, who announced in April that she was not seeking a second five-year term as chief prosecutor. There had been widespread speculation that Ms Saunders had been pressured into leaving her post after a series of controversies, including the collapse of a series of rape cases after the Crown Prosecution Service failed to disclo...

item.title: Director of public prosecutions criticised for 'insufficient leadership' over failings that saw evidence withheld from defence lawyers - The Independent
item.description:
Director of public prosecutions criticised for 'insufficient leadership' over failings that saw evidence withheld from defence lawyers  The Independent

Weak leadership by the director of public prosecutions failed to tackle failings that led to innocent people to be wrongly imprisoned, MPs have found. The Justice Committee warned that the impact of long-term issues with the disclosure of evidence had been gravely underestimated by the Crown Prosecution Service. The collapse of a series of rape cases last year sparked alarm over revelations that social media posts and messages proving suspects’ innocence had not been presented to courts. - Read more Dozens of sex prosecutions dropped because of evidence mistakes In January, the director of ...

item.title: Kenya: Busia county governor arrested on corruption charges - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
Kenya: Busia county governor arrested on corruption charges  Al Jazeera English

Busia county Governor Sospeter Ojaamong has been arrested and taken to court in Nairobi on multiple corruption charges. Ojaamong turned himself in to the headquarters of the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) where he spent four hours in remand before being taken to court on Wednesday. The Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) Noordin Haji laid the charges following a probe into the government's alleged loss of nearly $80,000 of public funds to a German company for waste management services. "Upon independent review of the file, I am satisfied that there is sufficient evidence to ...

item.title: Here’s another Jeremy Thorpe scandal – its chilling legacy in law - The Guardian
item.description:
Here’s another Jeremy Thorpe scandal – its chilling legacy in law  The Guardian

As the BBC TV dramatisation of the Thorpe scandal reaches its denouement this Sunday, millions will ask: why was Jeremy Thorpe acquitted of conspiring to kill Norman Scott? Because the judge was biased in his favour; because of the skill of his barrister, George Carman; or because he was innocent? None of the above. He was acquitted because of the dirtiest deal in media history, made by a rightwing newspaper. The significance of this deal was revealed by a jury member in the New Statesman, which was then itself prosecuted by the Thatcher government for contempt of court. The magazine’s vict...

item.title: Colin Humphrys among paedophiles SA Government wants to keep behind bars - ABC News
item.description:
Colin Humphrys among paedophiles SA Government wants to keep behind bars  ABC News

The South Australian Government says it has drafted legislation to keep dangerous paedophiles like Colin Humphrys behind bars, but it wants to see the outcome of the appeal in his case before it puts new laws before parliament. Humphrys has an extensive history of abuse against children, dating back to the 1990s, and was jailed indefinitely in 2009 over a case where he assaulted a boy in a toilet block in Port Adelaide. In 2016, the court was told Humphrys posed a high risk of reoffending if released back into the community. This year, the Supreme Court approved an application for his relea...

item.title: 'Waste of taxpayers' money': $100k audit delayed travel agent fraud investigation, court told - ABC News
item.description:
'Waste of taxpayers' money': $100k audit delayed travel agent fraud investigation, court told  ABC News

A $100,000 audit of the Northern Territory Health Department's pensioner travel concession scheme was "fluff", a waste of taxpayers' money and delayed a fraud investigation into the scheme, the NT Supreme Court has heard. Senior crown prosecutor David Morters has given evidence in the trial of former NT police commissioner John McRoberts, who has pleaded not guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice. Mr McRoberts is accused of trying to interfere in a travel agent fraud investigation — allegedly preventing the execution of an initial search warrant — because he had been in a sex...

item.title: Prosecutor warned police request to review DPP advice was 'political' - ABC News
item.description:
Prosecutor warned police request to review DPP advice was 'political'  ABC News

A senior crown prosecutor warned the Northern Territory Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) a request to review his advice about a major travel agent fraud investigation was "political", a court has heard. Senior crown prosecutor David Morters has given evidence in the trial of former NT police commissioner John McRoberts, who has pleaded not guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice. It is alleged Mr McRoberts tried to deflect an investigation into travel agents rorting the NT Health Department's pensioner concession scheme between May and November 2014 because he had a sexua...

item.title: Release of notorious paedophile Colin Humphrys to be appealed - ABC News
item.description:
Release of notorious paedophile Colin Humphrys to be appealed  ABC News

The South Australian Director of Public Prosecutions is appealing against a judge's decision to release notorious paedophile Colin Humphrys into the community. Humphrys has an extensive history of sexual offending against children, including the abduction and abuse of a boy in the early 1990s, and the sexual assault of a boy in a Port Adelaide toilet block in 2003. Humphrys had been serving an indefinite prison term, but Justice Trish Kelly last week approved an application allowing him to be released to live in the Bowden-Brompton area, in Adelaide's inner north-west. The decision to relea...

item.title: Former South African president Zuma faces charges over arms deal - ABC News
item.description:
Former South African president Zuma faces charges over arms deal  ABC News

Former South African president Jacob Zuma will face old charges of fraud, racketeering and money laundering, after prosecutors decided there were reasonable prospects of a successful prosecution. Key points: - Jacob Zuma faces charges including fraud and racketeering relating to 1990s arms contracts - Prosecutors say there are reasonable prospects of successful prosecution - The ruling African National Congress says the former President is innocent until proven guilty The move deepened the legal woes of a leader whose tenure was marked by scandals before he lost the support of the ruling Af...

item.title: Hillsborough relatives 'disgusted' by CPS decision over West Midlands police - The Guardian
item.description:
Hillsborough relatives 'disgusted' by CPS decision over West Midlands police  The Guardian

Relatives of the 96 people killed at Hillsborough in 1989 have severely criticised a decision by the Crown Prosecution Service not to charge any former West Midlands police officers with criminal offences relating to the force’s original investigation into the disaster. Margaret Aspinall, the chair of the Hillsborough Family Support Group whose 18-year-old-son James was killed in the disaster, said she was disgusted. She also criticised the CPS for failing to properly explain its decisions and the evidential threshold required to bring criminal charges. Two former West Midlands police offic...

item.title: Father who was high on ice when he confessed to killing his baby has murder charge dropped - ABC News
item.description:
Father who was high on ice when he confessed to killing his baby has murder charge dropped  ABC News

A Darwin man who was accused of killing his baby has had the murder charge against him dropped by the Director of Public Prosecutions. Brian James Baird went to a police station in September last year and told officers he had killed his infant child in 2015. He was taken into custody at the time and had been in jail since October, but it was revealed in the Darwin Local Court last month that the baby died of natural causes. There was also no evidence of abuse, the court heard at the time. Mr Baird's defence, Ian Read SC, explained the father was on ice at the time of the confession and was ...

item.title: Police reveal 'significant' new recordings in Neil-Fraser murder appeal case - ABC News
item.description:
Police reveal 'significant' new recordings in Neil-Fraser murder appeal case  ABC News

The last-chance appeal of convicted killer Sue Neill-Fraser has been adjourned again after revelations police obtained two films that the DPP says are "significant and important evidence". Neill-Fraser is serving a 23-year jail sentence for the 2009 murder of her partner Bob Chappell onboard their yacht moored off Hobart. She exhausted all other avenues of appeal, and is now relying on new last-chance appeal laws to have her convicted quashed. The application for the new appeal is part heard, and was due to return to court on Friday, but the court heard today the DPP will tender two films t...

item.title: Murder accused smeared dead man's blood on his face, court hears - ABC News
item.description:
Murder accused smeared dead man's blood on his face, court hears  ABC News

A man accused of the bashing murder of his friend during a camping trip near Interlaken smeared the blood of the dead man on his own face, the jury has heard. Russell John Nowoczynski, 47, has pleaded not guilty to the murder of Donald William Crow, 36, on a quiet road near Interlaken, north of Hobart, on June 12, 2016. The jury has heard Mr Crow's injuries were of a severity normally associated with a serious car accident. The court heard the pair had left Hobart to go camping near Interlaken and had been drinking throughout the afternoon, twice visiting Oatlands to buy alcohol. The jury w...

item.title: Don’t misread Alison Saunders. Silence during a rape doesn’t mean consent - The Guardian
item.description:
Don’t misread Alison Saunders. Silence during a rape doesn’t mean consent  The Guardian

Let’s start with clearing up the law. In the overwhelming majority of rape trials, the defendant will assert that the complainant was consenting, or that they reasonably believed the complainant was consenting. In such cases, the prosecution will have to make a jury sure, not only that consent was absent, but that the defendant believed it to be absent. This defence of reasonable belief has two components, and is almost completely fact-sensitive. The first component is whether the defendant genuinely believed that the complainant was consenting. The second is whether, in all the circumstanc...

item.title: Police forces and prosecutors failing to carry out 'basic' procedure in rape cases, Attorney General says - The Telegraph
item.description:
Police forces and prosecutors failing to carry out 'basic' procedure in rape cases, Attorney General says  The Telegraph

The failings which have lead to a nationwide review of all live rape and serious sexual assault cases were caused by police forces and prosecutors not carrying out “basic” procedure, the Attorney General has suggested. In a stinging criticism of authorities' handling a series of failed rape cases, Jeremy Wright QC has said there was “no excuse” and that there was a “substantial problem” with how disclosure protocol is followed. He also declined to say whether Alison Saunders, director of public prosecutions, should consider her position, but said that tackling the issue required a “joint ef...
